string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

search.slidetext: training for community peer researchers get started get started get started get started get started get started
what will this training cover? research ethics research design data collection data analysis writing and presenting research cultural competency personal development
module 1 research ethics

document their agreement. confirm participants understand the information. participants must choose freely to join. explain the project, its goals, and any risks. understanding informed consent use a consent form capacity to consent voluntary participation full disclosure of research purpose
understanding informed consent include consent option in surveys explain purpose before interviews

examples of informed consent clearly explained the aim of the study. clearly explained the aim of the study. clearly explained the aim of the study. clearly explained the aim of the study. clearly explained the aim of the study. clearly explained the aim of the study. informed participants about the activities or tasks theyll engage in. informed participants about the activities or tasks theyll engage in. informed participants about the activities or tasks theyll engage in. informed participants about the activities or tasks theyll engage in. informed participants about the activities or tasks theyll engage in. informed participants about the activities or tasks theyll engage in. provided an estimate of the time required for participation. provided an estimate of the time required for participation. provided an estimate of the time required for participation. provided an estimate of the time required for participation. provided an estimate of the time required for participation. provided an estimate of the time required for participation. explained how data will be collected, stored, and used. explained how data will be collected, stored, and used. explained how data will be collected, stored, and used. explained how data will be collected, stored, and used. explained how data will be collected, stored, and used. explained how data will be collected, stored, and used. assured anonymity (if applicable) and explained privacy protections. assured anonymity (if applicable) and explained privacy protections. assured anonymity (if applicable) and explained privacy protections. assured anonymity (if applicable) and explained privacy protections. assured anonymity (if applicable) and explained privacy protections. assured anonymity (if applicable) and explained privacy protections. stressed that participation is voluntary and can be withdrawn at any time. stressed that participation is voluntary and can be withdrawn at any time. stressed that participation provided details for questions provided details for questions provided details for questions obtained consent through signature, verbal agreement, or online checkbox. obtained consent through signature, verbal agreement, or online checkbox. obtained consent through signature, verbal agreement, or online checkbox. obtained consent through signature, verbal agreement, or online checkbox. obtained consent through signature, verbal agreement, or online checkbox. obtained consent through signature, verbal agreement, or online checkbox.
confidentiality and data protection anonymity and pseudonymity secure data storage limited access to data consent for data sharing

confidentiality and data protection imagine you are conducting a research study on employee mental health. youre interviewing participants and need to ensure that personal data remains confidential. how would you store the recorded interviews to protect confidentiality? in an unlocked folder on a shared drive. in an unlocked folder on a shared drive. in an unlocked folder on a shared drive. in an unlocked folder on a shared drive. in an unlocked folder on a shared drive. in an unlocked folder on a shared drive. in a password-protected folder, accessible only to authorised staff. in a password-protected folder, accessible only to authorised staff. in a password-protected folder, accessible only to authorised staff. in a password-protected folder, accessible only to authorised staff. in a password-protected folder, accessible only to authorised staff. in a password-protected folder, accessible only to authorised staff. on a usb with no access restrictions. on a usb with no access restrictions. on a usb with no access restrictions. on a usb with no access restrictions. on a usb with no access restrictions. on a usb with no access restrictions.
ethical dilemmas in research communicate openly seek guidance and reflect on actions consult ethical guidelines

ethical dilemmas in research youre reviewing survey responses and notice that a participant has given unlikely answers to several questions, such as stating they work 100 hours per week. how would you handle this? disregard the data entirely. disregard the data entirely. disregard the data entirely. disregard the data entirely. disregard the data entirely. disregard the data entirely. respect the response, but flag it for further review. respect the response, but flag it for further review. respect the response, but flag it for further review. respect the response, but flag it for further review. respect the response, but flag it for further review. respect the response, but flag it for further review. contact the participant to clarify. contact the participant to clarify. contact the participant to clarify. contact the participant to clarify. contact the participant to clarify. contact the participant to clarify.

below are several words that represent different approaches to handling ethical dilemmas in research. please drag and drop the words into the boxes that best describe your opinion on how to handle a situation where a participant has shared potentially sensitive information about workplace conflict. confidentiality consultation support immediate action non-interference ethical dilemmas in research
module 1 summary ethics essentials: consent, confidentiality, handling dilemmas
module 3 data collection

data collection data collection foundation of meaningful research purpose: gather accurate, reliable information focus areas: various methods (surveys, interviews, focus groups) cultural appropriateness in methods

surveys effective for large groups key tips: use clear, concise questions mix closed- and open-ended questions design user-friendly layout pilot test with a small group make accessible for all (e.g., language, literacy levels)

1 2 3 4 5 rate your experiences. how would you rate access to healthcare services in your area? how fair is the healthcare system in serving all patients? how well do healthcare providers meet individual needs? how accessible are healthcare facilities to you? how effective is healthcare policy in reducing treatment barriers? survey - example
please share any specific challenges you face in accessing healthcare services in your area. survey - example

which healthcare services do you feel are lacking or need improvement in your community? primary care (general practitioners) primary care (general practitioners) primary care (general practitioners) primary care (general practitioners) primary care (general practitioners) primary care (general practitioners) specialized care (e.g., cardiology, oncology) specialized care (e.g., cardiology, oncology) specialized care (e.g., cardiology, oncology) specialized care (e.g., cardiology, oncology) specialized care (e.g., cardiology, oncology) specialized care (e.g., cardiology, oncology) mental health services mental health services mental health services mental health services mental health services mental health services dental services dental services dental services dental services dental services dental services other other other other other other survey - example

interviews in-depth insights and perspectives prepare an open-ended question guide create a comfortable interview setting actively listen with empathy use follow-up questions to explore further respect cultural norms and sensitivities

sample interview stop conversion stop conversion stop conversion stop conversion stop conversion stop conversion resume conversion resume conversion resume conversion resume conversion resume conversion resume conversion

focus group interview group discussion for diverse insights recruit participants with varied perspectives use a flexible discussion guide create an inclusive, respectful environment encourage active participation record or take detailed notes (with permission)

focus group interview example example focus group: parent opinions on school health program discussion points: benefits of the proposed program concerns regarding implementation suggestions for improvement

cultural appropriateness respect participants' backgrounds and values adapt methods to be culturally sensitive use familiar language and terms be mindful of cultural norms and traditions train interviewers in cultural awareness seek community or expert feedback on materials

example of cultural appropriateness example: interviews with immigrant communities considerations: use interpreters when necessary adapt language for clarity and cultural relevance respect cultural nuances in responses
module 3 summary importance of accurate, reliable data collection. overview of methods: surveys, interviews, focus groups. role of cultural appropriateness in effective data collection
module 5 writing and presenting research

writing research reports purpose: convey findings in a structured format key tips: structure with clear sections (introduction, methods, results, discussion). write concisely, avoiding jargon. use tables, figures, or graphs to support findings. cite sources properly.

writing research reports example example topic: digital health interventions and patient outcomes. report structure: introduction: background on digital health in patient care. methods: data collection and analysis. results: impact on patient outcomes. discussion: implications and recommendations.

adapting to different audiences audience adaptation: tailor message to audience needs. approaches: academic: use formal, technical language; focus on theory and methods. policy: highlight practical implications and recommendations. community: use simple language and relatable examples.

adapting to different audiences example example topic: community health program benefits. approach: for policymakers: emphasise cost-effectiveness and public health impact. for community: focus on personal stories and positive local impact

visual presentation of findings visual aids: enhance clarity and engagement. techniques: use clear, concise slides with key points. incorporate charts, graphs, and infographics. add relevant images or illustrations to support concepts.

example of visual presentation example topic: barriers to healthcare access visuals used: maps to show geographic disparities. charts to display statistical data. infographics to summarise key barriers

effective communication strategies know your audience: tailor language and examples highlight relevance: emphasise significance and practical implications use storytelling: engage with relatable stories or examples

example of effective communication example topic: impact of digital health on chronic condition management communication techniques: use relatable stories to illustrate benefits. focus on practical takeaways for the audience. simplify complex data for accessibility
module 5 summary covered techniques for writing and presenting research. discussed adapting content for different audiences. explored visual and storytelling methods for clarity.
module 6 cultural competency

understanding cultural competency cultural competency: interacting effectively with diverse groups key aspects: challenge biases and stereotypes. develop cultural self-awareness. respect cultural differences without imposing values

example of cultural competency in research example: research on healthcare access among immigrants key considerations: recognise cultural barriers (e.g., language, trust in healthcare). adapt approach to respect cultural needs and concerns.

example of cultural competency in research when conducting research on healthcare access among immigrant communities, which of the following actions demonstrates cultural competency? only using english-language materials, as its the primary language of the country. only using english-language materials, as its the primary language of the country. only using english-language materials, as its the primary language of the country. only using english-language materials, as its the primary language of the country. only using english-language materials, as its the primary language of the country. only using english-language materials, as its the primary language of the country. assuming that cultural differences wont impact participants responses. assuming that cultural differences wont impact participants responses. assuming that cultural differences wont impact participants responses. assuming that cultural differences wont impact participants responses. assuming that cultural differences wont impact participants responses. assuming that cultural differences wont impact participants responses. providing translated materials and interpreters to ensure participants understand and feel comfortable. providing translated materials and interpreters to ensure participants understand and feel comfortable. providing translated materials and interpreters to ensure participants understand and feel comfortable. providing translated materials and interpreters to ensure participants understand and feel comfortable. providing translated materials and interpreters to ensure participants understand and feel comfortable. providing translated materials and interpreters to ensure participants understand and feel comfortable. focusing solely on healthcare providers' perspectives, as they understand the system best. focusing solely on healthcare providers' perspectives, as they understand the system best. focusing solely on healthcare providers' perspectives, as they understand the system best. focusing solely on healthcare providers' perspectives, as they understand the system best. focusing solely on healthcare providers' perspectives, as they understand the system best. focusing solely on healthcare providers' perspectives, as they understand the system best.

engaging with diverse communities build trust: listen actively, show empathy, be transparent collaborate: involve community members and seek their input adapt methods: align research practices with cultural norms

example of community engagement example: research on traditional healing practices engagement steps: collaborate with community leaders and elders. adapt methods to respect cultural practices. ensure the communitys perspective is represented

example of community engagement when engaging with a community to research traditional healing practices, which action best demonstrates effective community engagement? collaborating with community leaders and elders to gain insights. collaborating with community leaders and elders to gain insights. collaborating with community leaders and elders to gain insights. collaborating with community leaders and elders to gain insights. collaborating with community leaders and elders to gain insights. collaborating with community leaders and elders to gain insights. assuming that the community will accept the research methods as they are. assuming that the community will accept the research methods as they are. assuming that the community will accept the research methods as they are. assuming that the community will accept the research methods as they are. assuming that the community will accept the research methods as they are. assuming that the community will accept the research methods as they are. using only standardized methods that have been successful in other communities. using only standardized methods that have been successful in other communities. using only standardized methods that have been successful in other communities. using only standardized methods that have been successful in other communities. using only standardized methods that have been successful in other communities. using only standardized methods that have been successful in other communities.

overcoming cultural barriers language: provide translated materials and interpreters trust: partner with trusted community leaders or organizations cultural norms: adapt protocols to respect cultural practices

example of overcoming cultural barriers example: conducting a mental health survey in a multicultural neighbourhood steps taken: translated questionnaires provided in multiple languages. partnered with local organizations to build trust and credibility. offered culturally sensitive support services to ensure participant comfort.

example of overcoming cultural barriers in a multicultural neighbourhood, which action best demonstrates a culturally competent approach when conducting a mental health survey? using only the primary language of the country for all survey materials. using only the primary language of the country for all survey materials. using only the primary language of the country for all survey materials. using only the primary language of the country for all survey materials. using only the primary language of the country for all survey materials. using only the primary language of the country for all survey materials. partnering with local organizations and providing questionnaires in multiple languages. partnering with local organizations and providing questionnaires in multiple languages. partnering with local organizations and providing questionnaires in multiple languages. partnering with local organizations and providing questionnaires in multiple languages. partnering with local organizations and providing questionnaires in multiple languages. partnering with local organizations and providing questionnaires in multiple languages. relying on standardized methods without adapting to cultural sensitivities. relying on standardized methods without adapting to cultural sensitivities. relying on standardized methods without adapting to cultural sensitivities. relying on standardized methods without adapting to cultural sensitivities. relying on standardized methods without adapting to cultural sensitivities. relying on standardized methods without adapting to cultural sensitivities.

ensuring ethical conduct informed consent privacy and confidentiality addressing power dynamics clearly explain the studys purpose, risks, and benefits in a way participants fully understand, using culturally appropriate language and methods safeguard personal information according to both cultural expectations and legal standards to build trust and respect participants privacy be mindful of potential imbalances between researcher and participant, promoting respectful, equitable practices to create a safe, inclusive environment

example of ethical conduct example: interviewing individuals with mental health challenges ethical steps: ensure informed consent with clear, respectful explanations. create a safe, non-judgmental environment for open sharing. protect privacy and confidentiality throughout the process.
module 6 summary explored cultural competency in research. learned strategies for engaging diverse communities. discussed overcoming cultural barriers and ethical practices
module 8 community engagement and collaboration in research

understanding community engagement community engagement: actively involving the community in research key aspects: build trust and rapport identify key stakeholders ensure representation integrate community knowledge establish open, respectful relationships engage local leaders and representatives who can provide valuable insights include diverse voices to reflect the communitys needs and perspectives incorporate local insights and expertise into research design and implementation

example of community engagement example: co-designing research with a local community organization engagement steps: collaborate with community leaders to identify relevant research topics. involve community members as active participants in the research process. regularly consult with the community to refine and adjust research methods.

example of community engagement which of the following actions best demonstrates effective community engagement in a research project? conducting research independently and sharing the results with the community only at the end. conducting research independently and sharing the results with the community only at the end. conducting research independently and sharing the results with the community only at the end. conducting research independently and sharing the results with the community only at the end. conducting research independently and sharing the results with the community only at the end. conducting research independently and sharing the results with the community only at the end. collaborating with community leaders to identify relevant topics and involving community members as active participants. collaborating with community leaders to identify relevant topics and involving community members as active participants. collaborating with community leaders to identify relevant topics and involving community members as active participants. collaborating with community leaders to identify relevant topics and involving community members as active participants. collaborating with community leaders to identify relevant topics and involving community members as active participants. collaborating with community leaders to identify relevant topics and involving community members as active participants. relying solely on the researchers expertise to decide the focus and methods of the research. relying solely on the researchers expertise to decide the focus and methods of the research. relying solely on the researchers expertise to decide the focus and methods of the research. relying solely on the researchers expertise to decide the focus and methods of the research. relying solely on the researchers expertise to decide the focus and methods of the research. relying solely on the researchers expertise to decide the focus and methods of the research. conducting research without consulting the community to avoid influencing their responses. conducting research without consulting the community to avoid influencing their responses. conducting research without consulting the community to avoid influencing their responses. conducting research without consulting the community to avoid influencing their responses. conducting research without consulting the community to avoid influencing their responses. conducting research without consulting the community to avoid influencing their responses.

benefits of community engagement relevance trust and credibility co-creation of knowledge improved impact research findings are directly applicable to community needs building genuine relationships fosters trust and increases community buy-in diverse perspectives lead to richer insights and more comprehensive outcomes research outcomes are more likely to be utilised and valued by the community
example of benefits of community engagement example: gathering insights through community consultations benefits observed: increased relevance enhanced trust richer data higher utilisation

example of community engagement which of the following is a key benefit of conducting community consultations in research? ensuring the research remains entirely researcher-focused. ensuring the research remains entirely researcher-focused. ensuring the research remains entirely researcher-focused. ensuring the research remains entirely researcher-focused. ensuring the research remains entirely researcher-focused. ensuring the research remains entirely researcher-focused. building trust and gathering diverse insights that increase the relevance and impact of the research. building trust and gathering diverse insights that increase the relevance and impact of the research. building trust and gathering diverse insights that increase the relevance and impact of the research. building trust and gathering diverse insights that increase the relevance and impact of the research. building trust and gathering diverse insights that increase the relevance and impact of the research. building trust and gathering diverse insights that increase the relevance and impact of the research. limiting community input to avoid complicating the research process. limiting community input to avoid complicating the research process. limiting community input to avoid complicating the research process. limiting community input to avoid complicating the research process. limiting community input to avoid complicating the research process. limiting community input to avoid complicating the research process. conducting research without sharing findings back with the community. conducting research without sharing findings back with the community. conducting research without sharing findings back with the community. conducting research without sharing findings back with the community. conducting research without sharing findings back with the community. conducting research without sharing findings back with the community.

collaborative research approaches collaborative research: shared decision-making and equal partnerships key elements: value diverse knowledge open communication co-design capacity building recognise and integrate local knowledge and expertise alongside academic insights maintain regular, transparent communication with community partners work with the community to jointly develop research questions, methods, and solutions support the communitys ability to participate and lead in research processes

example of collaborative research example: partnering with a grassroots organization on healthcare access research collaborative actions: jointly identify research goals co-design research methods build local research capacity regular updates and feedback

ethical considerations in community engagement ethical engagement: ensuring respectful, fair, and transparent research practices key ethical principles: respect cultural values protect privacy and confidentiality informed consent continuous ethical review understand and honour the communitys beliefs, customs, and practices safeguard personal information and handle data in accordance with cultural and legal standards clearly explain research goals, risks, and benefits in accessible, culturally appropriate language regularly assess and adjust research activities to maintain ethical standards throughout the project

example of ethical engagement example: conducting research with a culturally diverse community ethical actions taken cultural sensitivity training transparent consent process privacy safeguards regular community check-ins

module 8 summary covered community engagement principles and collaborative approaches. discussed benefits of involving the community in research. explored ethical considerations essential for respectful research practices.

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue what are some key elements of collaborative research approaches? minimizing community involvement and input minimizing community involvement and input minimizing community involvement and input minimizing community involvement and input minimizing community involvement and input minimizing community involvement and input recognizing and valuing diverse knowledge systems recognizing and valuing diverse knowledge systems recognizing and valuing diverse knowledge systems recognizing and valuing diverse knowledge systems recognizing and valuing diverse knowledge systems recognizing and valuing diverse knowledge systems maintaining a hierarchical relationship between researchers and the community maintaining a hierarchical relationship between researchers and the community maintaining a hierarchical relationship between researchers and the community maintaining a hierarchical relationship between researchers and the community maintaining a hierarchical relationship between researchers and the community maintaining a hierarchical relationship between researchers and the community keeping community partners out of the decision-making process keeping community partners out of the decision-making process keeping community partners out of the decision-making process keeping community partners out of the decision-making process keeping community partners out of the decision-making process keeping community partners out of the decision-making process
